column2: This conversation will explain to the reader in part, the reason why Mrs. Huntington and her daughter, English subjects and in distress upon the coast, had not at once gone on board the vessel of their sovereign which lay in the harbor, and been carried upon their destination.
column3: This conversation will explain to the reader in part, the reason why mrs Huntington and her daughter, English subjects and in distress upon the coast, had not at once gone on board the vessel of their sovereign which lay in the harbor, and been carried upon their destination.

column2: From the outset Captain Bramble had resolved not to let his rival slip through his fingers by leaving port himself, and thus he had still remained to the present time, though without any definite plan of operation formed until he availed himself of Maud's proposal.
column3: From the outset Captain Bramble had resolved not to let his rival slip through his fingers by leaving port himself, and thus he had still remained to the present time, though without any definite plan of operation formed until he availed himself of Maud's proposal.

column2: Why, bless me, my child, you look as though you had been crying, said the mother, now, catching a glance at her daughter's face.
column3: Why, bless me, my child, you look as though you had been crying, said the mother, now, catching a glance at her daughter's face.

column2: Do I, mother? she answered, vacantly.
column3: Do I, mother? she answered, vacantly.

column2: This was just after she had returned from the meeting with Captain Ratlin as already described, and whether, she had been crying or not, the reader will probably know what feelings moved her heart.
column3: This was just after she had returned from the meeting with Captain Ratlin as already described, and whether, she had been crying or not, the reader will probably know what feelings moved her heart.

column2: CHAPTER XII.
column3: CHAPTER twelve.

column2: THE CONFLICT.
column3: THE CONFLICT.

column2: CAPTAIN BRAMBLE knew very well that he had desperate men to deal with in the taking of a slaver on the coast, but he had gathered his evidence and witnesses in such a strong array that he felt warranted in going to any length in securing possession of a clipper craft which had been so fully described to him.
column3: CAPTAIN BRAMBLE knew very well that he had desperate men to deal with in the taking of a slaver on the coast, but he had gathered his evidence and witnesses in such a strong array that he felt warranted in going to any length in securing possession of a clipper craft which had been so fully described to him.

column2: He was not wanting in personal courage, and therefore, with a well-selected body of sailors and marines, and one or two officers, he quietly pulled away from the ship's side, under cover of the night, and landed at the proposed spot.
column3: He was not wanting in personal courage, and therefore, with a well selected body of sailors and marines, and one or two officers, he quietly pulled away from the ship's side, under cover of the night, and landed at the proposed spot.

column2: Here he found Maud patiently awaiting his coming, and ready to lead him to the hiding-place of the "Sea Witch" and her crew.
column3: Here he found Maud patiently awaiting his coming, and ready to lead him to the hiding place of the "Sea Witch" and her crew.

column2: The men were all well armed, and instructed how to act in any possible emergency that was to be met with in the business which brought them on shore.
column3: The men were all well armed, and instructed how to act in any possible emergency that was to be met with in the business which brought them on shore.

column2: On the whole body pressed in silence, through a tangled and narrow path, being more than once startled by the growl of some wild animal, whose haunts they disturbed.
column3: On the whole body pressed in silence, through a tangled and narrow path, being more than once startled by the growl of some wild animal, whose haunts they disturbed.

column2: It was weary struggling by this path through the wood, but it was the only way to approach the desired point by land. Maud hesitated not, but stole or glided through the tangled undergrowth, as though she had passed her whole life-time in the deep, tangled ways of the jungle.
column3: It was weary struggling by this path through the wood, but it was the only way to approach the desired point by land. Maud hesitated not, but stole or glided through the tangled undergrowth, as though she had passed her whole life time in the deep, tangled ways of the jungle.

column2: As they went on, the moon gradually rose and lifted up the dark path by little gleamings which stole in through the thick leaves and close-turning branches of the lofty vegetation.
column3: As they went on, the moon gradually rose and lifted up the dark path by little gleamings which stole in through the thick leaves and close turning branches of the lofty vegetation.

column2: On, on they press; and now they pause at a sign from Maud, and listen to the sound of voices, which have a strange and echo-like sound in that wild and tangled spot.
column3: On, on they press; and now they pause at a sign from Maud, and listen to the sound of voices, which have a strange and echo like sound in that wild and tangled spot.

column2: Hark! those voices are not from the tongues of natives; that is English which they speak.
column3: Hark! those voices are not from the tongues of natives; that is English which they speak.

column2: Hist! hist! whispered the Quadroon, "we are almost upon them!"
column3: Hist! hist! whispered the Quadroon, "we are almost upon them!"

column2: In which direction? asked the English officer.
column3: In which direction? asked the English officer.

column2: Here, see you not those bright, silver-like scales through the leaves?
column3: Here, see you not those bright, silver like scales through the leaves?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: That is the river's bed, and they lie on board their craft, moored close to us.
column3: That is the river's bed, and they lie on board their craft, moored close to us.

column2: How many do they number?
column3: How many do they number?

column2: I know not.
column3: I know not.

column2: It is not important, continued the Englishman, turning to his followers, and in a low voice bidding them look to their weapons, for the game was near at hand.
column3: It is not important, continued the Englishman, turning to his followers, and in a low voice bidding them look to their weapons, for the game was near at hand.

column2: A few more steps brought the party to the skirts of the thicket, where it bordered on a small clearing, opening upon the river, and looking across which--while they were themselves screened by the jungle--they discovered the dark hull of the "Sea Witch," with her lower masts and their standing rigging.
column3: A few more steps brought the party to the skirts of the thicket, where it bordered on a small clearing, opening upon the river, and looking across which-while they were themselves screened by the jungle-they discovered the dark hull of the "Sea Witch," with her lower masts and their standing rigging.

column2: The vessel was moored close to the shore, with which a portable gangway connected it.
column3: The vessel was moored close to the shore, with which a portable gangway connected it.

column2: Shallow as the water was, yet so light was her draft that she evidently floated upon its sluggish current.
column3: Shallow as the water was, yet so light was her draft that she evidently floated upon its sluggish current.

column2: Voices were heard issuing from the fore hatch, and two or three petty officers were seated about the entrance to the cabin, smoking cigars and pipes, all unconscious of any danger.
column3: Voices were heard issuing from the fore hatch, and two or three petty officers were seated about the entrance to the cabin, smoking cigars and pipes, all unconscious of any danger.

column2: There is your prey!	There is your prey!
column3: true

column2: Spring upon it, and be quick, for they will fight like mad, and he will lay a dozen of you by the heels before you take the 'Sea Witch!'" said Maud.
column3: Spring upon it, and be quick, for they will fight like mad, and he will lay a dozen of you by the heels before you take the 'Sea Witch!'" said Maud.

column2: Captain Bramble rushed forward to the attack, followed by his men, and was soon on the deck of the vessel; but though he took Mr. Faulkner and his crew by surprise, he did not find them entirely unprepared, and after dropping eight of his people upon the slaver's deck, and being himself, severely wounded in the arm, Captain Bramble thought it best to beat a retreat, at least for a few moments, and so sought again the shelter of the jungle.
column3: Captain Bramble rushed forward to the attack, followed by his men, and was soon on the deck of the vessel; but though he took mr Faulkner and his crew by surprise, he did not find them entirely unprepared, and after dropping eight of his people upon the slaver's deck, and being himself, severely wounded in the arm, Captain Bramble thought it best to beat a retreat, at least for a few moments, and so sought again the shelter of the jungle.

column2: The conflict, which was very brief, was also a very sanguinary, and five of the slaver's people had been either mortally wounded or killed outright; but from the habit of constantly wearing their arms, even to pistols, when on the coast, they had been found in a very good situation at even the shortest notice for defending themselves.
column3: The conflict, which was very brief, was also a very sanguinary, and five of the slaver's people had been either mortally wounded or killed outright; but from the habit of constantly wearing their arms, even to pistols, when on the coast, they had been found in a very good situation at even the shortest notice for defending themselves.

column2: Captain Bramble now saw evident tokens of a purpose to unmoor the vessel, and let her drift out into the river, which would at once place her beyond his reach, as he had no boats within a league of the spot; and therefore he resolved upon a second onslaught, and this time divided his men into three parts--one to board at the bows, one at the stern, and himself leading a dozen picked men at the waist.
column3: Captain Bramble now saw evident tokens of a purpose to unmoor the vessel, and let her drift out into the river, which would at once place her beyond his reach, as he had no boats within a league of the spot; and therefore he resolved upon a second onslaught, and this time divided his men into three parts-one to board at the bows, one at the stern, and himself leading a dozen picked men at the waist.

column2: This division of his forces was the best manouvre he could possibly make, and succeeded admirably, since his own people outnumbered the slavers, and by dividing them he strengthened his own power and weakened theirs.
column3: This division of his forces was the best manouvre he could possibly make, and succeeded admirably, since his own people outnumbered the slavers, and by dividing them he strengthened his own power and weakened theirs.

column2: Once more upon their deck, the hand-to-hand battle was short, bloody and decisive, until towards its close, Captain Bramble found himself driven into the forecastle with a number of his followers, and at the same moment saw the mate of the "Sea Witch," with those of his people that were left alive hastening to embark in a quarterboat, and pull away from the vessel's side with great speed.
column3: Once more upon their deck, the hand to hand battle was short, bloody and decisive, until towards its close, Captain Bramble found himself driven into the forecastle with a number of his followers, and at the same moment saw the mate of the "Sea Witch," with those of his people that were left alive hastening to embark in a quarterboat, and pull away from the vessel's side with great speed.

column2: A sort of instinct explained to him the meaning of this, and hurrying his people on shore with the wounded, they sought the shelter of the jungle once more.
column3: A sort of instinct explained to him the meaning of this, and hurrying his people on shore with the wounded, they sought the shelter of the jungle once more.

column2: Scarcely had they gained the shade of the thick undergrowth, when a report like that of a score of cannons rang upon the night air, and high in the air soared a body of flame and wreck in terrific confusion.
column3: Scarcely had they gained the shade of the thick undergrowth, when a report like that of a score of cannons rang upon the night air, and high in the air soared a body of flame and wreck in terrific confusion.

column2: The slavers had placed a slow match in connection with the magazine, and had blown in one instant of time that entire and beautiful fabric into ten thousand atoms!
column3: The slavers had placed a slow match in connection with the magazine, and had blown in one instant of time that entire and beautiful fabric into ten thousand atoms!

column2: Even Maud, with all her hatred and passion, quailed at the shock, and trembled as she crouched to the ground with averted face.
column3: Even Maud, with all her hatred and passion, quailed at the shock, and trembled as she crouched to the ground with averted face.

column2: She realized the result of her treachery, but looked in vain for the object on whom she had hoped to reck the strength of her indignation and her hate. Where was he?
column3: She realized the result of her treachery, but looked in vain for the object on whom she had hoped to reck the strength of her indignation and her hate. Where was he?

column2: This was a question that Captain Bramble had several times asked; but in vain, until now, when suddenly there appeared before their eves, hastening towards the scene, Captain Will Ratlin.
column3: This was a question that Captain Bramble had several times asked; but in vain, until now, when suddenly there appeared before their eves, hastening towards the scene, Captain Will Ratlin.

column2: Seize him, my men! seize him, and bind his arms!--he is our prisoner, said the English officer.
column3: Seize him, my men! seize him, and bind his arms!--he is our prisoner, said the English officer.

column2: By what authority do you give such an order as that, Captain Bramble? asked the young commander.
column3: By what authority do you give such an order as that, Captain Bramble? asked the young commander.

column2: In the queen's name, sir; in the name of the English people, who abhor pirates and slavers! was the taunting reply of the Englishman.
column3: In the queen's name, sir; in the name of the English people, who abhor pirates and slavers! was the taunting reply of the Englishman.

column2: Stand back! said Captain Ratlin, felling two seamen to the earth who approached him to lay hands upon his person, and at the same time drawing a revolver from his pocket.
column3: Stand back! said Captain Ratlin, felling two seamen to the earth who approached him to lay hands upon his person, and at the same time drawing a revolver from his pocket.

column2: Stand back, I say!	Stand back, I say!
column3: true

column2: I carry the lives of six of you in this weapon, and I am not one to miss my aim, as your valiant leader yonder well knows.--Now, Captain Bramble, I will surrender to you, provided you accede to my terms, otherwise you cannot take me alive!"
column3: I carry the lives of six of you in this weapon, and I am not one to miss my aim, as your valiant leader yonder well knows.--Now, Captain Bramble, I will surrender to you, provided you accede to my terms, otherwise you cannot take me alive!"

column2: Well, sir, what have you to offer? said the English officer, positively quailing before the stern and manly front of the young commander.
column3: Well, sir, what have you to offer? said the English officer, positively quailing before the stern and manly front of the young commander.

column2: That you accept my word of honor to obey your directions as a prisoner, but that you shall not bind my arms or confine me otherwise.
column3: That you accept my word of honor to obey your directions as a prisoner, but that you shall not bind my arms or confine me otherwise.

column2: Have your own way, replied the Englishman, doggedly; "but give up your weapons."
column3: Have your own way, replied the Englishman, doggedly; "but give up your weapons."

column2: Do you promise me this, Captain Bramble?
column3: Do you promise me this, Captain Bramble?

column2: I do.
column3: I do.

column2: It is well, sir; there goes my weapon; saying which he hurled it far into the river's bed.
column3: It is well, sir; there goes my weapon; saying which he hurled it far into the river's bed.

column2: As soon as Maud saw him, she sprang to her feet, and with all the bitterness of expression which her countenance was capable of, she scowled upon his upright figure and handsome features.
column3: As soon as Maud saw him, she sprang to her feet, and with all the bitterness of expression which her countenance was capable of, she scowled upon his upright figure and handsome features.

column2: It was evident she felt a bitter disappointment at his absence from the late affray, and would only have rejoiced had she believed he was blown to atoms with his vessel by the wild explosion which had so lately shaken the very earth upon which she now stood.
column3: It was evident she felt a bitter disappointment at his absence from the late affray, and would only have rejoiced had she believed he was blown to atoms with his vessel by the wild explosion which had so lately shaken the very earth upon which she now stood.

column2: It was plain that up to this very moment, however, that the young commander had never suspected her of treachery, or even jealousy, towards himself; but now, he would have been worse than blind not to have seen and realized, also, the deep malignant feeling which was written on her dark, but handsome face.
column3: It was plain that up to this very moment, however, that the young commander had never suspected her of treachery, or even jealousy, towards himself; but now, he would have been worse than blind not to have seen and realized, also, the deep malignant feeling which was written on her dark, but handsome face.

column2: Maud, he said, in a low, but reproachful tone, "is it you who have betrayed us?"
column3: Maud, he said, in a low, but reproachful tone, "is it you who have betrayed us?"

column2: Ay, said the girl, quickly, and with a shrill cadence of voice, "a double heart should be dealt doubly with.
column3: Ay, said the girl, quickly, and with a shrill cadence of voice, "a double heart should be dealt doubly with.

column2: It was I who led these people hither, and I hoped the fate of so many of your ship's company might have been yours!--but you are a prisoner now, and there's hope yet!"
column3: It was I who led these people hither, and I hoped the fate of so many of your ship's company might have been yours!--but you are a prisoner now, and there's hope yet!"

column2: Maud, Maud! have I ever wronged you or your father? asked Captain Ratlin, reproachfully.
column3: Maud, Maud! have I ever wronged you or your father? asked Captain Ratlin, reproachfully.

column2: Do you not love that white-faced girl you brought hither?
column3: Do you not love that white faced girl you brought hither?

column2: And if I did, Maud, what wrong is that to thee?	And if I did, Maud, what wrong is that to thee?
column3: true

column2: Did I promise thee love?"
column3: Did I promise thee love?"

column2: Nay; I asked it not of you, said the angry girl.
column3: Nay; I asked it not of you, said the angry girl.

column2: But you have done me a great wrong, Maud; one that you do not yourself understand.	But you have done me a great wrong, Maud; one that you do not yourself understand.
column3: true

column2: I forgive you though, poor girl; you are hardly to blame."
column3: I forgive you though, poor girl; you are hardly to blame."

column2: These kindly-intended words only aggravated the object to whom they were addressed, and she turned away hastily to the shade of the thick vegetable growth, where he lost sight of her figure among the branches and leaves, while he walked on with the English officer and his people over the ground they had just passed, towards Don Leonardo's.
column3: These kindly intended words only aggravated the object to whom they were addressed, and she turned away hastily to the shade of the thick vegetable growth, where he lost sight of her figure among the branches and leaves, while he walked on with the English officer and his people over the ground they had just passed, towards Don Leonardo's.

column2: There being now no further cause for secrecy, they marched openly, and enlivened the way with many a rude jest, which grated harshly upon the ears of the wounded, who were borne upon litters made from branches of the hard, dry leaves of the palm.
column3: There being now no further cause for secrecy, they marched openly, and enlivened the way with many a rude jest, which grated harshly upon the ears of the wounded, who were borne upon litters made from branches of the hard, dry leaves of the palm.

column2: As they came upon the open spot where stand the barracoons and Don Leonardo's dwelling, they found the entire family aroused and on the watch, the heavy explosion of the "Sea Witch's" magazine having seemed to them like an earthquake.
column3: As they came upon the open spot where stand the barracoons and Don Leonardo's dwelling, they found the entire family aroused and on the watch, the heavy explosion of the "Sea Witch's" magazine having seemed to them like an earthquake.

column2: Don Leonardo, who shrewdly suspected the truth, seemed satisfied at a single glance as to the state of affairs, and walking up to the young commander, and watching for a favorable opportunity, when not overheard, he asked, significantly: "Treachery?"
column3: Don Leonardo, who shrewdly suspected the truth, seemed satisfied at a single glance as to the state of affairs, and walking up to the young commander, and watching for a favorable opportunity, when not overheard, he asked, significantly: "Treachery?"

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: Whom?
column3: Whom?

column2: It matters not, was the magnanimous reply; for Captain Ratlin was too generous to betray the Quadroon to her father, though she had proved thus treacherous to him.
column3: It matters not, was the magnanimous reply; for Captain Ratlin was too generous to betray the Quadroon to her father, though she had proved thus treacherous to him.

column2: As he now recognized himself to be a prisoner, and had been told by Captain Bramble that he must go forthwith on board his ship as such, he desired to say a few words to Mrs. Huntington and her daughter, a request which his rival could hardly find grounds for refusing, and so he took occasion to explain to them the state of affairs, and to advise them to the best of his ability, touching their own best course in order to safely reach England.
column3: As he now recognized himself to be a prisoner, and had been told by Captain Bramble that he must go forthwith on board his ship as such, he desired to say a few words to mrs Huntington and her daughter, a request which his rival could hardly find grounds for refusing, and so he took occasion to explain to them the state of affairs, and to advise them to the best of his ability, touching their own best course in order to safely reach England.

column2: They felt that his advice was good, as truly disinterested, and both agreed to abide strictly by it; but doubted not that as Captain Ratlin had not been engaged in any slave commerce, and indeed had not been in the late action at all, that he would be very soon liberated, and free to choose his own calling.
column3: They felt that his advice was good, as truly disinterested, and both agreed to abide strictly by it; but doubted not that as Captain Ratlin had not been engaged in any slave commerce, and indeed had not been in the late action at all, that he would be very soon liberated, and free to choose his own calling.

column2: Captain Ratlin was conveyed on board the ship in the harbor, and Mrs. Huntington and her daughter also, with Maud and some other witnesses that Captain Bramble desired; and the vessel shaped her course along the coast towards Sierra Leone, where there was sitting an English court of admiralty, with extraordinary authority relative to such cases Captain Bramble was now about to lay before them, and who would be only too much gratified at the bringing before them of an offender to make an example of him.
column3: Captain Ratlin was conveyed on board the ship in the harbor, and mrs Huntington and her daughter also, with Maud and some other witnesses that Captain Bramble desired; and the vessel shaped her course along the coast towards Sierra Leone, where there was sitting an English court of admiralty, with extraordinary authority relative to such cases Captain Bramble was now about to lay before them, and who would be only too much gratified at the bringing before them of an offender to make an example of him.

column2: Captain Bramble of course offered to Mrs. Huntington and her daughter his own cabin for their greater comfort, and strove to make their position as comfortable as possible for them while they were on board; but he had not the nice sense of honor, that true delicacy of spirit, which should have led him to remember they were his guests from necessity, and that to push a suit under such circumstances was not only indelicate but positively insulting.
column3: Captain Bramble of course offered to mrs Huntington and her daughter his own cabin for their greater comfort, and strove to make their position as comfortable as possible for them while they were on board; but he had not the nice sense of honor, that true delicacy of spirit, which should have led him to remember they were his guests from necessity, and that to push a suit under such circumstances was not only indelicate but positively insulting.

column2: And yet he did so; true, he did not actually importune Miss Huntington, but his attentions and services were all rendered under that guise and aspect which rendered them to her most repulsive.
column3: And yet he did so; true, he did not actually importune Miss Huntington, but his attentions and services were all rendered under that guise and aspect which rendered them to her most repulsive.

column2: Captain Bramble took good care that his prisoner and rival should have no degree of intercourse with her whom he knew very well Captain Ratlin loved.
column3: Captain Bramble took good care that his prisoner and rival should have no degree of intercourse with her whom he knew very well Captain Ratlin loved.

column2: Under pretence that he feared his prisoner would attempt to escape, he kept him under close guard, and did not permit him once upon deck during the entire trip from the factory of Don Leonardo to the harbor of Sierra Leone.
column3: Under pretence that he feared his prisoner would attempt to escape, he kept him under close guard, and did not permit him once upon deck during the entire trip from the factory of Don Leonardo to the harbor of Sierra Leone.

column2: This chafed the young commander's spirit somewhat, but yet he was of too true a spirit to sink under oppression; he was brave and cheerful always.
column3: This chafed the young commander's spirit somewhat, but yet he was of too true a spirit to sink under oppression; he was brave and cheerful always.

column2: Of course, Miss Huntington saw and understood all this, and the more heartily despised the English officer for the part he played in the unmanly business.
column3: Of course, Miss Huntington saw and understood all this, and the more heartily despised the English officer for the part he played in the unmanly business.

column2: Maud kept by herself.
column3: Maud kept by herself.

column2: She felt miserable, and as is often the case, realized that the success of her treachery, thus far, which, in her anticipation, had promised so much, had but still more deeply shadowed her heart.
column3: She felt miserable, and as is often the case, realized that the success of her treachery, thus far, which, in her anticipation, had promised so much, had but still more deeply shadowed her heart.

column2: The English officer looked upon her with mingled feelings of admiration for her strange beauty, with contempt for her treachery, and with a thought that she might be made perhaps the subject of his pleasure by a little management by-and-by.
column3: The English officer looked upon her with mingled feelings of admiration for her strange beauty, with contempt for her treachery, and with a thought that she might be made perhaps the subject of his pleasure by a little management by and by.

column2: It was natural for a heart so vile as his to couple every circumstance and connection in some such selfish spirit with himself; it was like him.
column3: It was natural for a heart so vile as his to couple every circumstance and connection in some such selfish spirit with himself; it was like him.

column2: Maud, he said to her, one day.
column3: Maud, he said to her, one day.

column2: Well, she answered, lifting her handsome face from her hands, where she often hid it.
column3: Well, she answered, lifting her handsome face from her hands, where she often hid it.

column2: You have lost one lover?
column3: You have lost one lover?

column2: The girl only answered by a flashing glance of contempt.
column3: The girl only answered by a flashing glance of contempt.

column2: How would you like another?
column3: How would you like another?

column2: Who? she said, sternly.
column3: Who? she said, sternly.

column2: Me! answered Captain Bramble.
column3: Me! answered Captain Bramble.

column2: You! she said, contemptuously, and with so much expression as to end the conversation.
column3: You! she said, contemptuously, and with so much expression as to end the conversation.

column2: No, he had not rightly understood the Quadroon; it was not wounded pride, that sentiment so easily healed when once bruised in the heart of a woman; it was not that which moved the laughter of the Spanish slaver--it was either love, or something very like it, turned to actual hate, and the native power of her bosom for revenge seemed to be now the food upon which she sustained life itself.
column3: No, he had not rightly understood the Quadroon; it was not wounded pride, that sentiment so easily healed when once bruised in the heart of a woman; it was not that which moved the laughter of the Spanish slaver-it was either love, or something very like it, turned to actual hate, and the native power of her bosom for revenge seemed to be now the food upon which she sustained life itself.

column2: Taking her lonely place in the cabin, after the conversation just referred to, she again hid her face in her hands, and remained with her head bowed in her lap for a long, long while, half dreaming, half waking.
column3: Taking her lonely place in the cabin, after the conversation just referred to, she again hid her face in her hands, and remained with her head bowed in her lap for a long, long while, half dreaming, half waking.

column2: Poor, untutored, uncivilized child of nature! she was very, very unhappy now.
column3: Poor, untutored, uncivilized child of nature! she was very, very unhappy now.
